source: Public Podcast – The ReadME Podcast: “More than meets the pull request”
episode: More than meets the pull request: maintainers talk contributions

level_1: This episode dives into how maintainers manage open-source contributions effectively.
It explains the basic etiquette: be polite, follow guidelines, and respect maintainers’ time.
level_2: Maintainers advise reading CONTRIBUTING.md and issue templates before starting work.
It's important to open clear, well-described issues instead of random questions.
level_3: They discuss handling community dynamics—when to enforce rules or be flexible.
Maintainers recommend good first issues for newcomers to build trust.
level_4: Advanced etiquette includes mentoring, managing community norms, and scaling contributions.
Senior maintainers share strategies for balancing openness and project quality.

level_1: Submitting a typo fix after reading project guidelines.
Tagging your PR as 'good first issue' when you're new.
level_2: Reporting a bug with clear steps and attaching logs/screenshots.
Asking maintainers for context before starting big work.
level_3: Maintainers triaging PRs, labeling them, and inviting review.
Organizing contribution sprints to onboard newcomers.
level_4: Leading community events like hacktoberfest or mentor programs.
Setting up policies for code-of-conduct and issue escalation.

level_1: Interns submit small docs fixes to get started.
level_2: Teams use CONTRIBUTING.md as onboarding docs for external contributors.
level_3: Maintainers use community forums to guide contributor growth.
level_4: Open-source leaders design contributor-friendly governance systems.

level_3: Plan: How will maintainers review my PR efficiently?
level_4: Build: How can I contribute to project standards and community?
